pending_diagnosis: DIAGNOSIS: Acute Intermittent Porphyria (AIP) THE SMOKING GUN: The unusual sequence of symptoms (GI -> Psychiatric -> Autonomic Instability -> Neuropathy) combined with the critical observation of the urine sample changing color upon exposure to light and air. This indicates the accumulation of porphyrin precursors. The recent initiation of the low-calorie diet (fasting) and the anti-epileptic medication (Gabapentin is an enzyme inducer) served as the potent triggers for the acute neurovisceral crisis. PATHOPHYSIOLOGY: AIP is an autosomal dominant metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme Hydroxymethylbilane Synthase (HMBS), previously known as Porphobilinogen Deaminase (PBGD). This deficiency leads to the buildup of highly neurotoxic precursors, specifically Aminolevulinic Acid (ALA) and Porphobilinogen (PBG), in the liver and nervous system. The accumulated PBG is unstable and spontaneously converts to porphobilin and porphyrins when exposed to light, oxidizing the urine from clear/yellow to deep reddish-brown or "port wine" color, often only after standing. The neurotoxicity affects the central, peripheral, and autonomic nervous systems, explaining the bizarre constellation of psychiatric symptoms, profound autonomic dysfunction (labile hypertension, tachycardia), and the severe, ascending neuropathy mimicking GBS.
